channel.title: New local problems on FixMyStreet
channel.description: The latest local problems reported by users

item.title: Roots of Tree Significant hazard to elderly, disabled & Children, 14th June
item.description:
I am writing to raise an urgent and ongoing concern regarding the condition of a tree located 48a Cambridge Road SW11 4RR directly to the side of Dental Beauty Battersea located 49 Kersley Street, which I have reported on several previous occasions (to incorrect departments) Despite prior complaints, the issue has now escalated and poses a significant hazard to vulnerable members of the public, including patients in wheelchairs, individuals using walking aids, and those with young children in buggies. The exposed and raised roots of this tree are creating an uneven and unstable surface which has already caused several close calls. Wheelchair users, in particular, are being tipped at precarious angles — and given the proximity of a brick wall, the risk of serious injury is alarmingly high. This situation is no longer a matter of minor inconvenience — it is a clear health and safety risk, and I fear that without immediate action, someone will be seriously harmed in the very near future. We request that the relevant team(s) urgently inspect the site and take immediate remedial action to address the tree root/ pavement issue. I would like to again reiterate this is written in response to 2 electric and 1 manaual wheelchair user verbally reporting these issues to us. Please confirm receipt of this message and provide an estimated timeline for investigation and resolution.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Kersley Street, Battersea, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Potholes on Leigham Court Road, 14th June
item.description:
These road defects have been there for 6 years and allowed to get worse as no attempts to do a decent repair job has been done. To just slap a bit of road surfacing on them and declare them fixed is rather pointless as two weeks later they will have fallen apart again. I have reported these issues more times than I care to remember and here we are in 2025 still waiting for them to be repaired. I shouldn’t be surprised by the shoddiness of the so called repairs but I would like to see one of the council people supposedly in charge cycle on this borough’s roads as I do every day then perhaps they might get an idea how pathetic the “fixes” are. Not holding my breath though.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Leigham Court Road, Streatham Hill, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Over hanging tree branches hazardous, 14th June
item.description:
Numerous trees are required pruning as their foliage has overgrown and are not only obstructing pedestrians but also are a significant hazard to the partially sighted. Blind members of the community are in danger and at risk. Please survey Ravenscroft road and other adjoining roads and streets to assess and prune the road side trees to address this hazard. ,
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Ravenscroft Road, Penge, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Trees need pruning, 14th June
item.description:
On Ravenscroft Rd between Elmers End Rd junction and Avenue Rd there are a number of trees which badly need cutting back. It is impossible to walk beneath them. I speak as a person who sustained an eye injury in the past from walking into overhanging branches. The trees are very dangerous for the sight-impaired. The problem has been escalating since the spring.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Ravenscroft Road, Penge, London
Report on FixMyStreet
